Yes, virtual reality (VR) is another technology being used by sports teams to give fans a more immersive and engaging experience, especially during the pandemic when in-person attendance is limited. Here are some examples:

1. NBA League Pass VR: The NBA has partnered with Intel to create NBA League Pass VR, which allows fans to watch live games in virtual reality. Fans can choose to watch from different camera angles, including courtside, and can interact with other fans in virtual chat rooms.

2. NFL VR: The NFL has also collaborated with NextVR to provide live VR streaming of games. Fans can watch the game from different angles, including behind the quarterback and in the huddle, and can interact with other fans.

3. Wimbledon VR: The Wimbledon tennis tournament has created a VR experience that allows fans to watch matches from different perspectives, including the front row and behind the baseline.

4. MLB VR Home Run Derby: Major League Baseball has created a VR experience that allows fans to participate in the Home Run Derby. Fans can bat and compete against other players in a virtual stadium.

5. NHL VR Experience: The National Hockey League has created a VR experience that allows fans to watch games from different angles, including in the penalty box and behind the goal.

These virtual reality experiences provide fans with a more immersive and interactive experience and allow them to feel more connected to the game and their favorite teams, even when they can't be there in person.
